co.cask.cdap.api.dataset.table
Interface Table

All Superinterfaces:
BatchReadable<byte[],Row>, BatchWritable<byte[],Put>, Closeable, Dataset
All Known Subinterfaces:
MemoryTable
All Known Implementing Classes:
IndexedTable
public interface Table
extends BatchReadable<byte[],Row>, BatchWritable<byte[],Put>, Dataset

An ordered, named table.

Method Detail

get

Row get(byte[] row)
Reads values of all columns of the specified row.

NOTE: Depending on the implementation of this interface and use-case, calling this method can be less efficient than calling the same method with columns as parameters because it can require making a round trip to the persistent store.

NOTE: objects that are passed in parameters can be re-used by underlying implementation and present in returned data structures from this method.

Parameters:
row - row to read from
Returns:
instance of Row: never null; returns an empty Row if nothing read

get

byte[] get(byte[] row,
           byte[] column)
Reads the value of the specified column of the specified row.

Parameters:
row - row to read from
column - column to read value for
Returns:
value of the column or null if the value is absent

get

Row get(byte[] row,
        byte[][] columns)
Reads the values of the specified columns of the specified row.

NOTE: objects that are passed in parameters can be re-used by underlying implementation and present in returned data structures from this method.

Returns:
instance of Row: never null; returns an empty Row if nothing read

get

Row get(byte[] row,
        byte[] startColumn,
        byte[] stopColumn,
        int limit)
Reads the values of all columns in the specified row that are between the specified start (inclusive) and stop (exclusive) columns.

NOTE: objects that are passed in parameters can be re-used by underlying implementation and present in returned data structures from this method.

Parameters:
startColumn - beginning of range of columns, inclusive
stopColumn - end of range of columns, exclusive
limit - maximum number of columns to return
Returns:
instance of Row; never null; returns an empty Row if nothing read

get

Row get(Get get)
Reads values of columns as defined by Get parameter.

NOTE: objects that are passed in parameters can be re-used by underlying implementation and present in returned data structures from this method.

Parameters:
get - defines read selection
Returns:
instance of Row: never null; returns an empty Row if nothing read

put

void put(byte[] row,
         byte[] column,
         byte[] value)
Writes the specified value for the specified column of the specified row.

Parameters:
row - row to write to
column - column to write to
value - to write

put

void put(byte[] row,
         byte[][] columns,
         byte[][] values)
Writes the specified values for the specified columns of the specified row.

NOTE: Depending on the implementation, this can work faster than calling put(byte[], byte[], byte[]) multiple times (espcially in transactions that alter many columns of one row).

Parameters:
row - row to write to
columns - columns to write to
values - array of values to write (same order as values)

put

void put(Put put)
Writes values into a column of a row as defined by the Put parameter.

Parameters:
put - defines values to write

delete

void delete(byte[] row)
Deletes all columns of the specified row.

NOTE: Depending on the implementation of this interface and use-case, calling this method can be less efficient than calling the same method with columns as parameters because it can require a round trip to the persistent store.

Parameters:
row - row to delete

delete

void delete(byte[] row,
            byte[] column)
Deletes specified column of the specified row.

Parameters:
row - row to delete from
column - column name to delete

delete

void delete(byte[] row,
            byte[][] columns)
Deletes specified columns of the specified row.

NOTE: Depending on the implementation, this can work faster than calling delete(byte[], byte[]) multiple times (especially in transactions that delete many columns of the same rows).

Parameters:
row - row to delete from
columns - names of columns to delete

delete

void delete(Delete delete)
Deletes columns of a row as defined by the Delete parameter.

Parameters:
delete - defines what to delete

incrementAndGet

long incrementAndGet(byte[] row,
                     byte[] column,
                     long amount)
Increments the specified column of the row by the specified amount and returns the new value.

Parameters:
row - row which value to increment
column - column to increment
amount - amount to increment by
Returns:
new value of the column
Throws:
NumberFormatException - if stored value for the column is not in the serialized long value format

incrementAndGet

Row incrementAndGet(byte[] row,
                    byte[][] columns,
                    long[] amounts)
Increments the specified columns of the row by the specified amounts and returns the new values.

NOTE: Depending on the implementation, this can work faster than calling incrementAndGet(byte[], byte[], long) multiple times (especially in a transaction that increments multiple columns of the same rows)

NOTE: objects that are passed in parameters can be re-used by underlying implementation and present in returned data structures from this method.

Parameters:
row - row whose values to increment
columns - columns to increment
amounts - amounts to increment columns by (in the same order as the columns)
Returns:
Row with a subset of changed columns
Throws:
NumberFormatException - if stored value for the column is not in the serialized long value format

incrementAndGet

Row incrementAndGet(Increment increment)
Increments the specified columns of a row by the specified amounts defined by the Increment parameter and returns the new values

NOTE: objects that are passed in parameters can be re-used by underlying implementation and present in returned data structures from this method.

Parameters:
increment - defines changes
Returns:
Row with a subset of changed columns
Throws:
NumberFormatException - if stored value for the column is not in the serialized long value format

increment

void increment(byte[] row,
               byte[] column,
               long amount)
Increments (atomically) the specified row and columns by the specified amounts, without returning the new value.

Parameters:
row - row which values to increment
column - column to increment
amount - amount to increment by

increment

void increment(byte[] row,
               byte[][] columns,
               long[] amounts)
Increments (atomically) the specified row and columns by the specified amounts, without returning the new values. NOTE: depending on the implementation this may work faster than calling increment(byte[], byte[], long) multiple times (esp. in transaction that changes a lot of rows)

Parameters:
row - row which values to increment
columns - columns to increment
amounts - amounts to increment columns by (same order as columns)

increment

void increment(Increment increment)
Increments (atomically) the specified row and columns by the specified amounts, without returning the new values. NOTE: depending on the implementation this may work faster than calling increment(byte[], byte[], long) multiple times (esp. in transaction that changes a lot of rows)

Parameters:
increment - the row and column increment amounts

scan

Scanner scan(@Nullable
             byte[] startRow,
             @Nullable
             byte[] stopRow)
Scans table.

Parameters:
startRow - start row inclusive; null means start from first row of the table
stopRow - stop row exclusive; null means scan all rows to the end of the table
Returns:
instance of Scanner

getSplits

List<Split> getSplits(int numSplits,
                      byte[] start,
                      byte[] stop)
Returns splits for a range of keys in the table.

Parameters:
numSplits - Desired number of splits. If greater than zero, at most this many splits will be returned. If less than or equal to zero, any number of splits can be returned.
start - if non-null, the returned splits will only cover keys that are greater or equal
stop - if non-null, the returned splits will only cover keys that are less
Returns:
list of Split

compareAndSwap

boolean compareAndSwap(byte[] key,
                       byte[] keyColumn,
                       byte[] oldValue,
                       byte[] newValue)
                       throws Exception
Compares-and-swaps (atomically) the value of the specified row and column by looking for an expected value and, if found, replacing it with the new value.

Parameters:
key - row to modify
keyColumn - column to modify
oldValue - expected value before change
newValue - value to set
Returns:
true if compare and swap succeeded, false otherwise (stored value is different from expected)
Throws:
Exception
